Literature Review: The ductile deformation of the lithospheric mantle plays a crucial role in understanding plate tectonics and the strength of lithospheric plates. This review focuses on the experimental constraints on olivine deformation, as olivine is the primary mineral constituent of the upper mantle and, by extension, the lithosphere.Olivine deformation is governed by four primary mechanisms: low-temperature plasticity, dislocation creep, dislocation-accommodated grain-boundary sliding (GBS), and diffusion-accommodated grain-boundary sliding (diffusion creep). Each of these mechanisms dominates under specific conditions, contributing to the complex behavior of the lithospheric mantle.Low-temperature plasticity is particularly relevant in the brittle-ductile transition zone. Mei et al. (2010) conducted experiments on olivine at low temperatures and high stresses, providing valuable insights into the deformation behavior in this regime. Their findings suggest that low-temperature plasticity may play a significant role in governing the strength of the lithosphere at the brittle-ductile transition.Dislocation creep has been extensively studied and is well-characterized for olivine. Hirth and Kohlstedt (2003) compiled a comprehensive review of olivine rheology, including dislocation creep mechanisms. Their work highlights the importance of this deformation mechanism at high stresses and relatively low temperatures, conditions that may prevail in certain parts of the lithospheric mantle.Dislocation-accommodated grain-boundary sliding (GBS) has emerged as a dominant deformation mechanism in much of the lithosphere. Hansen et al. (2011) conducted experiments on olivine aggregates and found that GBS becomes increasingly important at conditions relevant to the lithospheric mantle. Their results suggest that GBS may be the primary deformation mechanism in large portions of the lithosphere, particularly at intermediate stress and temperature conditions.Diffusion creep, or diffusion-accommodated grain-boundary sliding, becomes dominant in fine-grained regions and at low stresses. Faul and Jackson (2007) investigated the influence of water content on diffusion creep in olivine, demonstrating its significance in hydrous conditions. Their work suggests that diffusion creep may be particularly important in shear zones within the lithospheric mantle, where grain size reduction and elevated water content can promote this deformation mechanism.The extrapolation of experimentally derived flow laws to geological conditions has been a subject of ongoing research and debate. Kohlstedt and Hansen (2015) reviewed the consistency between laboratory-derived flow laws and observations from naturally deformed rocks. They found general agreement between experimental predictions and natural observations, lending credibility to the application of laboratory-derived flow laws to geological timescales and conditions.However, a significant discrepancy exists between the strength of the lithosphere predicted by experimental studies and that inferred from geophysical observations. Bürgmann and Dresen (2008) discussed this paradox, highlighting the need for further research to reconcile laboratory and field observations. They suggested that processes occurring in the brittle-ductile transition zone, where the lithosphere is strongest, may hold the key to resolving this discrepancy.The role of water in olivine deformation has been a focus of numerous studies. Karato and Jung (2003) investigated the effects of water on olivine rheology and found that even small amounts of water can significantly influence deformation mechanisms and rates. Their work underscores the importance of considering water content when interpreting lithospheric strength and deformation behavior.Recent advances in experimental techniques have allowed for more precise measurements of olivine deformation at conditions closer to those in the lithospheric mantle. Holtzman et al. (2018) used torsion experiments to investigate olivine deformation at high pressures and temperatures, providing new insights into the transition between different deformation mechanisms.The spatial and temporal variations in lithospheric strength remain an active area of research. Précigout and Gueydan (2009) modeled the evolution of lithospheric strength, considering the interplay between different deformation mechanisms. Their work highlights the dynamic nature of lithospheric strength and the importance of considering multiple deformation mechanisms when interpreting geophysical observations.In conclusion, while significant progress has been made in understanding the ductile deformation of the lithospheric mantle through experimental studies on olivine, challenges remain in reconciling laboratory results with geophysical observations. Future research should focus on bridging this gap, particularly by investigating processes in the brittle-ductile transition zone and considering the complex interplay between different deformation mechanisms under varying conditions of stress, temperature, grain size, and water content.
